Posts.Content: JoanQuilts wrote: I am not currently "just diagnosed," but I've been "just diagnosed" twice in the past, once 20 years ago and then again a year ago.  If any one of you watch the NBC series "Parenthood," (SPOILER ALERT!!!!!), you will know that one of the main characters was just diagnosed with breast cancer.  They deal with it in the final minutes of last week's episode. Watching the character's reaction was like hurtling me back to that point 20 years ago.  Of EVERYTHING I've been through, I think the point of first diagnosis was the absolute worst.  I could see myself in her face, her body language, her reaction - I think they captured it perfectly. Did anyone else see this episode - if so, what did you think? Joan Diagnosed 10/92, lumpectomy, CMF. Diagnosed with second primary 12/11 (19 years later!). . BMX with TEs to implants; 6 rounds of TC. Dx 12/6/2011, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/0 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Surgery 1/6/2012 Mastectomy: Left, Right; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Chemotherapy 2/6/2012 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 02:05PM JoanQuilts wrote:  This is a really great discussion.  Here's my story:  I was diagnosed 19 years ago, at age 34, with IDC, a 2 cm, node negative tumor.  My surgeon simply told me I would have a lumpectomy, radiation and chemo - I was relieved I didn't need a mastectomy at the time, and didn't know enough to ask why. Fast forward these 19 years.  Last month, I was diagnosed with a DCIS and an 8 mm IDC in the SAME BREAST.  As we know, we can't re-radiate the same breast, so a mast. in the left breast is called for.  Since I am still only 53 and it appears that I have a tendency towards bc (even though I am BRCA negative), I have chosen to have a bilateral mastectomy.  I decided 1)  two breast cancers in one lifetime is enough   2) I will have a better chance at a matching set if we do both at the same time.  I've elected TEs with implants.  While I would have enjoyed the tummy tuck, I am looking for a shorter rather than a longer recovery time and avoiding messing with the rest of my body.  I am a large busted girl (but otherwise small) so I am looking forward to going smaller. Like all of us (it seems), I am scared to look at myself after surgery (which is on Friday). I'm not sure I'll ever feel totally comfortable that the bc won't come back (apparently it was highly unusual for me to develop a new primary after 19 years), but at least I won't be worrying about the right side in addition to the left. So we all have our reasons for choosing our own paths.  The most important is that YOU do the choosing.  It is a very empowering feeling. Joan

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2013 04:08PM JoanQuilts wrote: I'm in the camp of BRCA 1 and 2 negative; HOWEVER, I had my first breast cancer at a very young age (34) and just last year -19 years later - was diagnosed with second.  Even my oncologist says that I may have a mutation that has not yet been discovered.  Since I had a BMX the second time around, I am not so worried about my remaining breast tissue (little as there may be), but about my ovaries, which are very much intact.  My onco is against having them removed, as he says the risks of surgical complications outweigh the risks of ovarian cancer for me; my gyno says it's a relatively simple procedure these days to remove the ovaries.   Fortunately, I don't obsess over it.  But sometimes I wonder what, if anything, is going on with my ovaries.  I went into chemopause with my first round of chemotherapy when I was 34.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2012 05:07PM JoanQuilts wrote: My question for you, Staystrong, is how did you find a doctor who would operate on you on a Saturday???? That said, I had a BMX last January and got through it pretty easily.  I remember waking up in recovery and asking my PS about my nodes.  Then I remember being wheeled into my room and transferred to my bed.  I had control of pain meds through a pump, but just had some achiness.  I spent two nights in the hospital, rested at home for a couple of weeks and was back at school/work soon afterwards.  I have since gone through chemo, had my TE's exchanged for permanent implants and look and feel great.  I, too, am afraid of anaesthesia, but one minute you're talking to the docs, the next minute it's all over.  They may give you something to relax you before administering the anaesthesia. I will be thinking of you and wishing you the best. Don't catastrophize -  I know, easier said than done.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 07:58AM JoanQuilts wrote: PS - First time, I either wore my wig everywhere or a turban when I went to sleep.  This time, I either wear a scarf/hat at home or go commando (when I'm home alone).  A few days ago I said to my husband, would you mind if I show you what I look like without my hat/wig (I hadn't done that the first time - too afraid of freaking the both of us out).  He said yes, so I did.  Then I told him that I was going to start sleeping without a head covering because it's the only time of the day when I feel truly comfortable.  So that's what I've been doing.  It is very comfortable to sleep and I'm so glad for the 8 hours or so when I feel like myself (considering that I can't sleep on my stomach because of my TEs).
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 12:34PM JoanQuilts wrote: I salute all of you brave ladies who go topless!  I am pretty sure that I would never have the courage to do that, but I do go out quite a bit in scarves and hats but always wear a wig to work and school. Since this is my second bout with cancer, the first one being when I was much younger, I feel I've matured enough to not care as much what other people think.  The last time I was never without my wig.  I usually wear a scarf or turban to bed, but found that there was always a knot somewhere pressing into my neck.  So I asked my husband if it would freak him out if I went "without" to bed.  He said no and I must say I am never more comfortable than I am in bed at night completely topless. Have any of you started to grow back your hair mid-treatment?  The last time I had chemo, I believe that my hair started to grow back somewhere around my last treatment.  This time I lost most, but not all of my hair and the hair that is remaining looks like it needs a haircut!  Since that hair is growing, I wonder whether the remaining hair will start to grow in sooner as well.  I am halfway through 6 sessions of T/C.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 09:26AM JoanQuilts wrote: 19 years ago, after my first breast cancer diagnosis, I was going through the round of scans.  I was laying down on the table watching the screen where my bone scan was appearing.  I saw a huge brightly lit round shape take form and thought to myself, "Oh shit, that's the humongous tumor that's going to kill me."  The technician came in, glanced at the screen, glanced at me and said, "You'd better go empty your bladder."  Since then I always look away during scans and other tests.  So happy for your news. Joan

Posts.Content: JoanQuilts wrote: 17 days after my 1st chemo treatment, right on schedule, my hair is coming out in fistfuls and I've started to wear my wig.  It actually looks pretty good (better than my own) but for some reason I feel ASHAMED to be wearing it. My friends, family and colleagues know about my battle with bc and have been incredibly supportive.  Yet to appear in front of them for the first time makes me so anxious and I'm not sure why.  I wonder whether I'm afraid that they PITY me or that they are imagining how awful I look under the wig or equate my being bald with me dying. Does anyone else feel this way? Given that my own hair is not so great, I probably look better with the wig, but I hate to appear in public this way.  Diagnosed 10/92, lumpectomy, CMF. Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2012 07:55AM JoanQuilts wrote: When I had chemo 19 years ago, I had my last infusion in June.  My hair had already started to grow back at little before the last infusion.  I wore my wig through January - so about 7 months, at which point I had a nice head of thick, curly hair - very different from what I had looked like before I lost my hair. I could have gone without my wig before then, but I'm very sensitive and didn't want to walk around with TOO short a haircut.  This time, though, I think I will ditch the wig earlier.  I just don't like the feel of the wig on my head, I care less about what people think (not that they're thinking anything bad) than I did when I was younger and it will probably be easier to go short than shoulder length.  I try not to think about my hair - just get through the day to day. It will come back in due time. Joan

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2012 08:54PM JoanQuilts wrote: The one good thing to come out of my hair loss is that I no longer feel so self-conscious about myself.  I have always been pretty conservative in terms of dress and hairstyle.  The first time I had cancer, I wore my wig for nearly a year all the time - in and outside the house.  This time, I have only worn the wig when I had to go to work or an interview.  I've been wearing bandanas and hats the entire summer; today I am wearing a beautiful turban.  In many ways it feels liberating - I can change my look as often as I like and I am not at all self-conscious (in fact, since I am on the "inside looking out" I completely forget what I look like to others). My hair is growing in - I am 10+ weeks PFC- and I am willing to bet that I will be going "topless" when my hair is at a much shorter stage than it was when I had cancer 19 years ago.  I guess that's the difference - at least for me  - between having cancer when you're 34 and having it when you're 54 - increased confidence.  :) Joan

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 06:52PM JoanQuilts wrote: Hi Sonant - I just had a bilateral mastectomy 10 days ago.  19 years ago I was diagnosed with a small left breast cancer, which was treated by lumpectomy, radiation and chemo. I thought I was out of the woods when I was diagnosed last month with both a DCIS and an IDC, on the same side as the bc 19 years ago.  Given that I had already undergone rads on that side I had no choice but a mastectomy.  The breast MRI showed NO cancer on the right, but I decided to have the right one removed prophylactically.  I am still only 53 years old and I feel that two breast cancers in one lifetime is enough.  I don't want to go through this again. That said, this was the right decision for ME.  I wish you the best in making the decision that is best for you. Joan

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 07:15PM JoanQuilts wrote: Sonant - I was in the hospital for two nights, but it was actually a shorter stay because my surgery didn't start until about 6 p.m. the first night.  I did use two pillows under the seatbelt on my way home from the hospital. It's a 45 minute drive and when we hit a couple of bumps, I felt it, but it wasn't too bad.  The volunteers at the hospital make these little pillows and I got two of them -  you may be able to get them from organizations locally. Someone else mentioned silk pajamas and there was one point where I was trying to manuever myself around bed that I thought to myself, "Wow!  Silk would be so helpful here!"  So I think you made a great purchase!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 12:58PM JoanQuilts wrote: I had a lumpectomy, rads and chemo 19 years ago and was diagnosed with a new primary in the same breast back in December.  Because that breast had already been radiated, I had no choice but to have a mastectomy.  I thought I would simply have a reduction on the right side to have a matching pair, until my surgeon brought up the idea of doing a bilateral.  At first I was horrified, but then it began to make sense.  I'm still only 53 and I've already had two breast cancers - I don't want to sit around waiting for a third.  I have absolutely no regrets.  Good luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Unilateral vs. Bilateral MX: regrets? jgisme GreenEyes57

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2012 05:33AM JoanQuilts wrote: The magic bullet?  TIME.  You are barely one year past your initial diagnosis.  That is a mega-second in cancer time.   I was diagnosed with bc 19 years ago and it took me a good 2-3 years to start feeling like myself again.  Which is not to say that I stopped worrying about a recurrence - but that I wasn't constantly consumed with fear.  But I can honestly say that eventually I did stop worrying in advance of my physical appointments and bc started to seem like a distant memory. What can you do in the meantime?  Join a support group.  I have attended and RUN support groups where the women absolutely glow - because they are in an environment where others truly understand.  The bonds they forge are unbreakable.  Find an activity that you enjoy - go to the theatre, start a jewelry making class, take up yoga.  Listen to music that makes your heart sing.  Get outside and talk a walk.  Relaxation exercises - mediation. And yes - meds.  I don't think an onc should be prescribing medication - it is a psychiatrist who specializes in this and should be helping you out. And now the kicker - after 19 years I was diagnosed with a new primary breast cancer (a very small one) for which I am in treatment.  And because I learned how to "live" after my first diagnosis, the second one has been easiER - not easy, but easier.  (I am reluctant to tell women that I've been rediagnosed, but it is a rare occurence and I like to think I've taken the bullet for all of you). What is that expression?  Depression is not a sign of weakness - it's a sign that you've been strong for too long.  Give yourself a break, sistah - and remember we are here for you!
Posts.Title: Running out of places to turn to for help NoMoreHL karen333

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 08:28PM JoanQuilts wrote: Dr. Tartter of St. Luke's Roosevelt did my lumpectomy when I was first diagnosed with bc 20 years old.  He continued to follow me for 19 years.  I was diagnosed with a new primary last year and chose to be treated in New Jersey where I currently live.  Dr. Tartter is a very good surgeon.  I didn't always like his bedside manner, but he was ALWAYS there for me through my fears and questions.  Best of luck in making your decision.
Posts.Title: NYC Breast Surgeon Recommendation Please NYCMs Zer35

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2012 06:56PM JoanQuilts wrote: I'm sorry Sonant - I didn't see your reply until now.  I am feeling very, very well 11 days post BMX.  I'm not in pain - just achy from the TEs - which I think is almost unavoidable. I was sleepy the first week, but am getting out now - to the mall, to lunch with friends, and am starting class tomorrow (I am in grad school).  There are a lot of great tips on this board.  Wear easy to pull up pants (sweats) home from the hospital, a front buttoning shirt (it will be hard to lift your arms over your head), USE your pain meds - they are your friends!  Let everyone "do" for you.  If you don't have people clamoring to cook meals for you, cook and freeze in advance.  The two most useful things my family/friends/community have done for me were to deliver meals and to gift me with money to have my house cleaned.  I don't particularly like to talk on the phone, so I kept everyone updated on FB.  Caringbridge.org is also a great site to keep everyone updated.   Just rest, rest, rest.  And take it day by day.  I don't know if you will need further treatment, but if you do, don't stress over rads or chemo now.  Just concentrate on your surgery - one step at a time. I know it may sound strange to some of the ladies on this board, but I didn't stress too much over losing my breasts - I looked at it as an opportunity.  I have always been much too big breasted for my 5' 2" height.  Now, when I look at myself  post mastectomy (which wasn't THAT difficult, by the way), I have the beginnings of cute little perky breasts.  I am dreaming of all the strapless dresses and summer shirts I'll be able to wear in a few months. Most importantly, I am keeping you in my thoughts and prayers.  Feel free to emai me privately if you'd like.  Joan

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2012 05:47PM - edited Sep 9, 2012 05:48PM by JoanQuilts Just to clarify what dltnhm said above, a lumpectomy plus radiation is equivalent to mastectomy IN TERMS OF THE RISK FOR A DISTANT METASTASIS.  This has been accepted for more than 20 years ago based on extensive clinical trials comparing the survival rates of women who had a lumpectomy plus rads vs. a mastectomy for early stage cancer.  However, a mastectomy is more effective in terms of avoiding a LOCAL RECURRENCE.  I am evidence of that.  I had a lumpectomy plus rads 20 years ago, but had a new primary in the affected breast just last year.  Had I had a mastectomy at the time, the local recurrence most likely would not have occurred.
